---

Modern beauty standards are not just about aesthetics—they are deeply tied to the mechanisms of capitalist production. The emphasis on appearance, from skin to makeup, functions as a form of commodity fetishism, where the body becomes a surface for consumption and a site of value extraction. The pressure to conform to idealized looks—whether through skincare routines, fashion, or makeup like mascara—serves to reinforce a system in which the proletariat is not only alienated from the means of production but also from their own bodies. In this way, beauty becomes a tool for surplus value extraction, as individuals are compelled to invest time, money, and labor into maintaining a marketable appearance, all under the guise of self-care and empowerment.

---
